issue.title: Add MacOS window manager
issue.body:
```
global frontApp, frontAppName, windowTitle

set windowTitle to ""
tell application "System Events"
	set frontApp to first application process whose frontmost is true
	set frontAppName to name of frontApp
	tell process frontAppName
		tell (1st window whose value of attribute "AXMain" is true)
			set windowTitle to value of attribute "AXTitle"
		end tell
	end tell
end tell

return {frontAppName, windowTitle}
```

`osascript active_window.scpt`

issue.title: Add MacOS window manager
issue.body:
```
global frontApp, frontAppName, windowTitle

set windowTitle to ""
tell application "System Events"
	set frontApp to first application process whose frontmost is true
	set frontAppName to name of frontApp
	tell process frontAppName
		tell (1st window whose value of attribute "AXMain" is true)
			set windowTitle to value of attribute "AXTitle"
		end tell
	end tell
end tell

return {frontAppName, windowTitle}
```

`osascript active_window.scpt`

issue.title: fix loot - use proper monster level for generating items

labels.name: vanilla
labels.description: Bugs found also in the original Diablo 1.09b release

labels.name: critical
labels.description: A bug that is super serious

milestone.description: Catch up to the many PR that have been submitted

issue.body:
This is the most important PR ever - this is the reason why loot was the same on all difficulties, hell, it was even worse than that, despite unique monsters having a custom data table with lvls and level getting increased by 4 for item generating, it was always taking the level of base monster straight from the data table - means no bonus from difficulty, no bonus from being unique xD

I did the math for lazarus (30 lvl) on hell (+30 lvl)
that alone brings him to 60, he has 0 in unique data level, so that's a +5 bonus and there's a flat +4 bonus hardcoded on top of that so final level would be 69.
According to

```cpp
enum icreateinfo_flag {
	// clang-format off
	CF_LEVEL        = (1 << 6) - 1,
```
Max item level can be 63 (not sure if before or after that hardcoded +4 bonus), so we'd need to cap the level to max range.

#Added capping the level to 63, hardcoded +4 for bosses happens after the level gets loaded so we effectively have max lvl 67 items!

comment.body: For one second I thought the 2930 was merged.

issue.title: Oriented Bounding Box
issue.body:
This PR adds a new class that represents an oriented bounding box (OBB). It can be really useful as hitbox, the example shows how it can be done using Intersector. It also works when the camera is rotated.

![Screenshot from 2021-11-26 10-35-08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1824878/143620164-f049380d-a12b-4409-bcaa-f218f411ee45.png)
Image explained: All the boxes are blue by default, when two boxes collide they become yellow, when your mouse is over one of the boxes, it becomes lime green.

issue.title: Concurrecy: allow using LIBGDX in a multicontext-mutithreaded application
issue.body:
This PR allow using LIBGDX in a multicontext-mutithreaded application by getting rid of static fields.

We used thread locals where needed, which are proven to be very fast and have little or no impact to the current LIBGDX performance.

At the same time we removed a lot of unneeded static field declarations.

Plus we added an option in order to allow applications already loading LWJGL natives to avoid re-loading them from LIBGDX
Use **GdxNativesLoader.disableLwjglNativesLoading** = true;

This PR has been deeply tested and does not introduce any api/behavior change

comment.body:
Hey, @MikOfClassX having multithreading in libgdx is something that I would like having for a long time, thanks for taking time to work on it.

You mentioned that it was deeply tested, would you mind sharing what profiling/benchmarking tools did you use? And examples to force different threads to call the same piece of code?

Still about the examples, I couldn't find in your code any logic to load meshes only on a certain GL Context, other might know that better than me but when I tried multithreading a long time ago, that was really painful, I am curious to understand how you solve it.

I made some comments on the code regarding new instantiations, although it works, memory will increase a lot specially in apps that are heavy already, I suggest you to use a poll instead.

Another huge change you made is adding those Data structures to classes, it would work, as long as you have one data structure for each thread. It is not elegant but would work.

Because it is a very critical feature, I suggest you to add tests to help people to understand how deep this PR is tested.

I would be glad to review new iterations.

 	 * the same as {@link Vector3#mul(Matrix4)} applied to multiple vectors.
-	 * @param mat the matrix
-	 * @param vecs the vectors
-	 * @param offset the offset into the vectors array
+	 * @param mat     the matrix
+	 * @param vecs    the vectors
+	 * @param offset  the offset into the vectors array

-	public static native void mulVec (float[] mat, float[] vecs, int offset, int numVecs, int stride) /*-{ }-*/; /*

issue.title: Spell text revision
issue.body:
Visual explanation:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830720-19967302-0f1f-45f6-89c7-877473d27a88.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830728-21775656-ac2b-43f1-a32c-fea59ae02fe2.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830730-7650ab9f-f8e3-4ec2-aa62-0f092efc343c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830741-91a3f724-e996-4c26-a805-97acfb4ae8e7.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830755-ef240396-1a65-4d27-a2d4-eecf7ba7e08b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830872-194bf170-c354-48a0-b703-74863b1ab668.png)

Text explanation:
This changes the spellbook to be more uniform with the character panel. In the character panel, red is used to signify when stats are lower than base, and blue is used to signify when stats are higher than base. Also gold is used when a stat is maxed out. I used this method for the spellbook, as well and showing exactly how many spell levels are being gained or lost from items.

On top of that, I revised how spell information is shown for skill and staves. In vanilla, you were given no information other than the fact a skill is a skill, or how many charges a staff has remaining. This gives the player access to that missing information.

issue.title: fix loot - use proper monster level for generating items

labels.name: vanilla
labels.description: Bugs found also in the original Diablo 1.09b release

labels.name: critical
labels.description: A bug that is super serious

milestone.description: Catch up to the many PR that have been submitted

issue.body:
This is the most important PR ever - this is the reason why loot was the same on all difficulties, hell, it was even worse than that, despite unique monsters having a custom data table with lvls and level getting increased by 4 for item generating, it was always taking the level of base monster straight from the data table - means no bonus from difficulty, no bonus from being unique xD

I did the math for lazarus (30 lvl) on hell (+30 lvl)
that alone brings him to 60, he has 0 in unique data level, so that's a +5 bonus and there's a flat +4 bonus hardcoded on top of that so final level would be 69.
According to

```cpp
enum icreateinfo_flag {
	// clang-format off
	CF_LEVEL        = (1 << 6) - 1,
```
Max item level can be 63 (not sure if before or after that hardcoded +4 bonus), so we'd need to cap the level to max range.

#Added capping the level to 63, hardcoded +4 for bosses happens after the level gets loaded so we effectively have max lvl 67 items!

issue.title: Concurrecy: allow using LIBGDX in a multicontext-mutithreaded application
issue.body:
This PR allow using LIBGDX in a multicontext-mutithreaded application by getting rid of static fields.

We used thread locals where needed, which are proven to be very fast and have little or no impact to the current LIBGDX performance.

At the same time we removed a lot of unneeded static field declarations.

Plus we added an option in order to allow applications already loading LWJGL natives to avoid re-loading them from LIBGDX
Use **GdxNativesLoader.disableLwjglNativesLoading** = true;

This PR has been deeply tested and does not introduce any api/behavior change

comment.body:
Hey, @MikOfClassX having multithreading in libgdx is something that I would like having for a long time, thanks for taking time to work on it.

You mentioned that it was deeply tested, would you mind sharing what profiling/benchmarking tools did you use? And examples to force different threads to call the same piece of code?

Still about the examples, I couldn't find in your code any logic to load meshes only on a certain GL Context, other might know that better than me but when I tried multithreading a long time ago, that was really painful, I am curious to understand how you solve it.

I made some comments on the code regarding new instantiations, although it works, memory will increase a lot specially in apps that are heavy already, I suggest you to use a poll instead.

Another huge change you made is adding those Data structures to classes, it would work, as long as you have one data structure for each thread. It is not elegant but would work.

Because it is a very critical feature, I suggest you to add tests to help people to understand how deep this PR is tested.

I would be glad to review new iterations.

comment.diff_hunk:

 	 * the same as {@link Vector3#mul(Matrix4)} applied to multiple vectors.
-	 * @param mat the matrix
-	 * @param vecs the vectors
-	 * @param offset the offset into the vectors array
+	 * @param mat     the matrix
+	 * @param vecs    the vectors
+	 * @param offset  the offset into the vectors array

-	public static native void mulVec (float[] mat, float[] vecs, int offset, int numVecs, int stride) /*-{ }-*/; /*
+	public static native void mulVec(float[] mat, float[] vecs, int offset, int numVecs, int stride) /*-{ }-*/; /*

issue.title: Spell text revision
issue.body:
Visual explanation:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830720-19967302-0f1f-45f6-89c7-877473d27a88.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830728-21775656-ac2b-43f1-a32c-fea59ae02fe2.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830730-7650ab9f-f8e3-4ec2-aa62-0f092efc343c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830741-91a3f724-e996-4c26-a805-97acfb4ae8e7.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830755-ef240396-1a65-4d27-a2d4-eecf7ba7e08b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830872-194bf170-c354-48a0-b703-74863b1ab668.png)

Text explanation:
This changes the spellbook to be more uniform with the character panel. In the character panel, red is used to signify when stats are lower than base, and blue is used to signify when stats are higher than base. Also gold is used when a stat is maxed out. I used this method for the spellbook, as well and showing exactly how many spell levels are being gained or lost from items.

On top of that, I revised how spell information is shown for skill and staves. In vanilla, you were given no information other than the fact a skill is a skill, or how many charges a staff has remaining. This gives the player access to that missing information.

issue.title: Add MacOS window manager
issue.body:
```
global frontApp, frontAppName, windowTitle

set windowTitle to ""
tell application "System Events"
	set frontApp to first application process whose frontmost is true
	set frontAppName to name of frontApp
	tell process frontAppName
		tell (1st window whose value of attribute "AXMain" is true)
			set windowTitle to value of attribute "AXTitle"
		end tell
	end tell
end tell

return {frontAppName, windowTitle}
```

`osascript active_window.scpt`

issue.body:
This is the most important PR ever - this is the reason why loot was the same on all difficulties, hell, it was even worse than that, despite unique monsters having a custom data table with lvls and level getting increased by 4 for item generating, it was always taking the level of base monster straight from the data table - means no bonus from difficulty, no bonus from being unique xD

I did the math for lazarus (30 lvl) on hell (+30 lvl)
that alone brings him to 60, he has 0 in unique data level, so that's a +5 bonus and there's a flat +4 bonus hardcoded on top of that so final level would be 69.
According to

```cpp
enum icreateinfo_flag {
	// clang-format off
	CF_LEVEL        = (1 << 6) - 1,
```
Max item level can be 63 (not sure if before or after that hardcoded +4 bonus), so we'd need to cap the level to max range.

#Added capping the level to 63, hardcoded +4 for bosses happens after the level gets loaded so we effectively have max lvl 67 items!

issue.title: Oriented Bounding Box
issue.body:
This PR adds a new class that represents an oriented bounding box (OBB). It can be really useful as hitbox, the example shows how it can be done using Intersector. It also works when the camera is rotated.

![Screenshot from 2021-11-26 10-35-08](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1824878/143620164-f049380d-a12b-4409-bcaa-f218f411ee45.png)
Image explained: All the boxes are blue by default, when two boxes collide they become yellow, when your mouse is over one of the boxes, it becomes lime green.

issue.title: Concurrecy: allow using LIBGDX in a multicontext-mutithreaded application
issue.body:
This PR allow using LIBGDX in a multicontext-mutithreaded application by getting rid of static fields.

We used thread locals where needed, which are proven to be very fast and have little or no impact to the current LIBGDX performance.

At the same time we removed a lot of unneeded static field declarations.

Plus we added an option in order to allow applications already loading LWJGL natives to avoid re-loading them from LIBGDX
Use **GdxNativesLoader.disableLwjglNativesLoading** = true;

This PR has been deeply tested and does not introduce any api/behavior change

comment.body:
Hey, @MikOfClassX having multithreading in libgdx is something that I would like having for a long time, thanks for taking time to work on it.

You mentioned that it was deeply tested, would you mind sharing what profiling/benchmarking tools did you use? And examples to force different threads to call the same piece of code?

Still about the examples, I couldn't find in your code any logic to load meshes only on a certain GL Context, other might know that better than me but when I tried multithreading a long time ago, that was really painful, I am curious to understand how you solve it.

I made some comments on the code regarding new instantiations, although it works, memory will increase a lot specially in apps that are heavy already, I suggest you to use a poll instead.

Another huge change you made is adding those Data structures to classes, it would work, as long as you have one data structure for each thread. It is not elegant but would work.

Because it is a very critical feature, I suggest you to add tests to help people to understand how deep this PR is tested.

I would be glad to review new iterations.

issue.title: Spell text revision
issue.body:
Visual explanation:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830720-19967302-0f1f-45f6-89c7-877473d27a88.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830728-21775656-ac2b-43f1-a32c-fea59ae02fe2.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830730-7650ab9f-f8e3-4ec2-aa62-0f092efc343c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830741-91a3f724-e996-4c26-a805-97acfb4ae8e7.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830755-ef240396-1a65-4d27-a2d4-eecf7ba7e08b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68359262/190830872-194bf170-c354-48a0-b703-74863b1ab668.png)

Text explanation:
This changes the spellbook to be more uniform with the character panel. In the character panel, red is used to signify when stats are lower than base, and blue is used to signify when stats are higher than base. Also gold is used when a stat is maxed out. I used this method for the spellbook, as well and showing exactly how many spell levels are being gained or lost from items.

On top of that, I revised how spell information is shown for skill and staves. In vanilla, you were given no information other than the fact a skill is a skill, or how many charges a staff has remaining. This gives the player access to that missing information.
